metadata.title: Antibacterial properties of nano-silver coated PEEK prepared through magnetron sputtering

Antibacterial properties of nano-silver coated PEEK prepared through magnetron sputtering
Xiuju Liua, Kang Ganb, Hong Liua,∗, Xiaoqing Songa, Tianjie Chena, Chenchen Liua
a Department of General Dentistry, School and Hospital of Stomatology, Jilin University,1500 Qing Hua Road, Changchun 130021, PR China b Dental Center, The First Affiliated Hospital of Zhengzhou University, Zhengzhou 450000, PR China
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 11 January 2017 Received in revised form 21 March 2017 Accepted 22 June 2017
Keywords: PEEK Nano-silver Cytotoxicity Antibacterial property
a b s t r a c t
Objectve. We aimed to investigate the cytotoxicity and antibacterial properties of nano-silvercoated polyetheretherketone (PEEK) produced through magnetron sputtering and provide a theoretical basis for its use in clinical applications. Methods. The surfaces of PEEKs were coated with nano-silver at varying thicknesses (3, 6, 9, and 12 nm) through magnetron sputtering technology. The resulting coated PEEK samples were classified into the following groups according to the thickness of the nano-silver coating: PEEK-3 (3 nm), PEEK-6 (6 nm), PEEK-9 (9 nm), PEEK-12 (12 nm), and PEEK control group. The surface microstructure and composition of each sample were observed by scanning electron microscopy (SEM), atomic force microscopy (AFM), and energy dispersive spectrum (EDS) analysis. The water contact angle of each sample was then measured by contact angle meters. A cell counting kit (CCK-8) was used to analyze the cytotoxicity of the mouse fibroblast cells (L929) in the coated groups (n = 5) and group test samples (n = 6), negative control (polyethylene, PE) (n = 6), and positive control group (phenol) (n = 6). The antibacterial properties of the samples were tested by co-culturing Streptococcus mutans and Straphylococcus aureus. The bacteria that adhered to the surface of samples were observed by SEM. The antibacterial adhesion ability of each sample was then evaluated. Results. SEM and AFM analysis results showed that the surfaces of control group samples were smooth but compact. Homogeneous silver nano-particles (AgNPs) and nano-silver coating were uniformly distributed on the surface of the coated group samples. Compared with the control samples, the nano-silver coated samples had a significant increase in surface roughness (P < 0.05) as the thickness of their nano-silver coating increased. EDS analysis showed that not only C and O but also Ag were present on the surface of the coated samples. Moreover, the water contact angle of modified samples significantly increased after nanosilver coating modification (P < 0.01). CCK-8 cytotoxicity test results showed that coated samples did not exhibit cytotoxicity. The antibacterial experimental results showed that the nano-silver coating can significantly improve the antibacterial activity and bacterial adhesion ability of the PEEK samples. Significance. The compact and homogeneous nano-silver coating was successfully prepared

. Introduction
wing to the increase in the aging population, the number f patients with dentition defect or loss is increasing annully. In addition, cases of bone defects caused by trauma, umor resection, or infection has increased recently. Conseuently, the demand for oral implant materials increases. t present, titanium and titanium alloys are the most comonly used medical implant materials especially in dental mplants and fixation materials for bone defects and fracure splints, because they demonstrate good clinical effect. owever, the mismatch between the elastic modulus of the itanium implant materials and human bone tissues prouces a “stress shielding effect” after implantation [1], and hereby leading to implant loosening and even implantation ailure. Moreover, when used as a dental implant, titanium
etal exhibits changes in its appearance because it is readly exposed and causes allergic reactions in some patients [2]. herefore, for the resolution of these problems and increase f the success rate of implantation surgery, exploring new mplant materials is extremely important. As a member of the poly (aryl ether ketone) family,
olyetherether ketone (PEEK) is a special thermoplastic polyer because it exhibits good mechanical properties, such
s high strength, high rigidity, corrosion resistance, hydrolsis resistance, and good biocompatibility [3,4]. As a medical mplant material exhibiting excellent performance, PEEK has een approved by the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA). ompared with titanium, PEEK has an elastic modulus of –4 GPa, which is approximate to that of human cortical bone. urthermore, PEEK can be retained during clinical examinaion (such as X-ray, CT, MRI) and diagnosis because of its ood plastic and semi ray transmissions [5]. During the1990s, EEK composite materials were extensively used as metal mplant replacements in the field of orthopedics and trauma 6]. In 1992, PEEK was first used in dental applications and as mainly used in the manufacture of temporary abutment, mplant abutment, and healing cap [7]. Currently, PEEKs are xtensively used as implants in various medical fields such as rthopedics, spine surgery, and craniofacial surgery, because f their satisfactory clinical effects [8–10].
Implant materials must exhibit not only good biologial activity but also good antibacterial properties. Presently, esearch for the improvement of the biological activities of he PEEK implants is gradually maturing and is focused n modification strategies, such as surface coating modication, chemical etching, plasma surface treatment, and lasma immersion ion implantation. For example, nitrogenontaining functional groups were successfully integrated on
PEEK surface through nitrogen ion implantation, and the esulting modified PEEK demonstrated enhanced biological
activity [11,12]. However, PEEK has poor antibacterial ability. In addition, studies on the antibacterial activity of PEEK are currently immature. Meanwhile, implant inflammation instigated by plaque is the most frequent complication of implant surgery and is the leading cause of implant failure [13,14]. After an in vivo implantation, bacteria can quickly attach to the surface of the implant. Bacteria firmly attach on the implant surface through the specific binding of their cell surfaces with the receptors on the acquired film and formatted plaque biofilm [15]. The biofilm renders the bacteria highly resistant to the host defense response and antimicrobial agents, and thus results in chronic infection and bone resorption around the implants; as such, implant loosening and shedding eventually results in implantation failure [16]. Therefore, preventing the inflammation around the implant by modifying the implant material is an important strategy that can inhibit the adhesion of bacteria and formation of biofilm. This inhibitory effect can improve the antibacterial property of the implant material.
Silver has good anti-inflammatory and bactericidal properties. Notably, the antibacterial properties of silver are already long acknowledged and extensively applied. As a nonspecific broad-spectrum antibacterial agent, silver is used as support in the surface of the implant to enhance the antibacterial properties of the latter. Compared with silver ions, nano-silver exhibits quantum effect, small-size effect, and large specific surface area, presents some distinguishing features, such as durable antibacterial property, broad antibacterial spectrum, and low toxicity [17,18] and has been applied to a variety of medical materials and equipment, such as wound dressings, catheters, blood vessels, and bone fixation devices, to prevent infection [19]. Therefore, preparation of a nano-silver modified layer on the surface of a material is presently receiving considerable attention because this process can improve the antibacterial properties of the material. Wan et al. and Cao et al. [20,21] found that implanting silver ions onto the surface of titanium and titanium alloy enhances the antibacterial properties of these materials. Moderate silver on the surface of material can improve antibacterial property without adversely affecting cell proliferation and differentiation.
Magnetron sputtering is a high-speed and low-temperature deposition technology developed in during the 1970s. It can prepare uniform and strong adhesion film on the surface of polymers, composite materials, and ceramics [16]. The basic principle of the magnetron sputtering is as follows: The plasma in Ar and O2 mixed gas subjected to an electric field and alternating magnetic fields and high-energy particles accelerated the bombardment of the target surface. After the energy exchange, the atoms of the target surface escape from the original atomic lattice, and then transfer to the surface of the substrate, and finally form a film. The entire process is extremely fast, and it requires low temperature and
3 ( 2 xxx.e350 d e n t a l m a t e r i a l s 3
generates low damage. Magnetron sputtering requires simple equipment and thus is easy to control. In addition, it has low substrate temperature, high film forming rate, and strong film adhesion [22].
Huang et al. [23] prepared silver coating on the surface of tantalum oxide through magnetron sputtering. The resulting silver-cotated tantalum oxide exhibited increase in water contact angle, improved hydrophobicity, and good antibacterial properties to Straphylococcus aureus. Similarly, Gao et al. [16] prepared silver coating on the surface of titanium implants through magnetron sputtering, and their antibacterial experiment showed that the silver-coated titanium implants exhibited long-term antibacterial effects against S. aureus and Escherichia coli (the antibacterial rate was maintained above 97%).
The aim of this present study was to investigate the cytotoxicity and antibacterial effect of nano-silver modification on PEEK. There were three hypotheses as follows: (1) The compact and homogeneous nano-silver modified layer was prepared on the surface of PEEK by magnetron sputtering. (2) The modified PEEK implants have no cytotoxicity. (3) The antibacterial activity and bacterial adhesion ability of the modified PEEK implants are enhanced significantly. So, we provided a solid foundation for the broad clinical application of PEEK and its composites in the fields of joint replacement, bone defect repair, and dental implantation.
2. Materials and methods
2.1. Sample preparation
Two sets of biomedical grade standard PEEK disks were obtained from Jilin University Super Engineering Plastics Research Co., Ltd., China. One set contained the PEEK disks with diameters of 10 mm and thickness of 1 mm, while the other set contained those with diameters of 40 mm and thickness of 2 mm. Prior to surface treatment, all the disks were ground with 600-, 800-, 1000-, 1200-, and 1500-grit silicon carbide abrasive papers. Then they were ultrasonically cleaned using acetone, ethanol, and deionized water in an ultrasonic water bath (Euronda, Italy) for 30 min. After air-drying carefully, they were randomly divided into the control group (PEEK group) and the nano-silver coating groups. All the PEEKs of the nano-silver coating groups were modified using a magnetron sputtering apparatus (SBC-12, Beijing KYKY technology CO., Ltd., China). The schematic of nano-silver coating through magnetron sputtering on PEEK is illustrated in Fig. 1. During the process, the distance between the 99.99% silver target and the standard test piece was 5 cm, and the room temperature vacuum was adjusted to 3 × 103 Pa. Approximately 40 sccm of argon was then subjected to a work pressure of 0.5 Pa. The nano-silver coatings at thicknesses of 3, 6, 9, and 12 nm were deposited onto the PEEKs through magnetron sputtering under 80 W. The modified PEEKs were divided into the following groups according to coating thickness: PEEK-3 (3 nm), PEEK-6 (6 nm), PEEK-9 (9 nm), and PEEK-12 (12 nm).

2.2. Surface characterization
The surface morphologies of the modified PEEK samples were assessed using scanning electron microscopy (SEM, S-4800, Hitachi, Japan). The chemical compositions of the samples were detected by energy dispersive spectrometer (EDS, QUANTAX 400, Luke AXS Co., Germany). The three-dimensional morphologies of the sample surfaces were characterized through atomic force microscopy (AFM, Veeco Instruments, USA). The surface roughness of each sample was also acquired. Furthermore, the water contact angle of each sample was measured by contact angle measurement (DSA20, MK2 KR SS Edward Keller company, Germany) using the hanging drop method using deionized water on the surface of the samples at different positions. For statistical accountability, the average of the five contact angle measurements of each sample was obtained.
2.3. Cytotoxicity test in vitro
2.3.1. Preparation of disinfection and extraction solution of the samples The samples were wiped with 75% alcohol and rinsed with deionized water thrice. After drying, the samples were transferred to a clean bench (BLB-1300, Suzhou Sujing baishen Technology Co., Ltd.) and subjected to UV irradiation for 2 h and then turned over after 1 h. A high glucose culture medium (Nanjing Jiancheng biological Co., China) was added to the culture medium containing the sterile test piece. The resulting culture medium was then placed in a CO2 incubator (MCO20IL, Sanyo, Japan) at 37 ◦C for 72 h to prepare the extraction solution.
2.3.2. CCK-8 cytotoxicity test The logarithmic growth phase mouse fibroblast cell suspension (L929, Cells Resource Center, Shanghai Institutes of Biological Science, China) with a concentration of 2 × 104/ml was added to 96-well plates (Costar, USA). Each hole contained 2000 cells. The following groups were then used for subsequent experiment: blank control (pure high glucose medium), negative control (PE), positive control (phenol), PEEK, PEEK-3, PEEK-6, PEEK-9 and PEEK-12. The marked 96-wellplates were placed at a cell incubator (5%CO2, 95% humidity). After incubation for 24 h at 37 ◦C, the supernatant was removed and 100 l extraction solution was added into each hole. After incubation for 1, 3, 5, and 7 days, 10 lCCK-8 agentia (CCK-8, Sigma, USA) was added into each hole in darkness and then incubated for 2 h at 37 ◦C in a CO2 cell incubator. The absorbance (A) of the supernatant was measured using a microplate reader (BL340, Biotech, USA) at 450 nm wave length. The relative growth rate (RGR) of the cells was calculated using the following formula: RGR = experimental group A value/blank control group A value × 100%. Furthermore, the toxicity levels of the samples and the safety standards were determined according to Table 1.

2.4.3. Antibacterial adhesion test 2.4.3.1. Bacterial adhesion plate colony count. Approximately 2 ml of bacterial suspension (1 × 109 CFU L−1) was co-cultured with sterile samples under anaerobic environment for 48 h. All the samples were then taken out sequentially from the bacterial suspension and rinsed thrice with sterile PBS buffer for 10 s to remove non-adherent bacteria. The adherent bacteria were detached ultrasonically from the samples in10 ml of the same PBS buffer for 5 min. After the solution was diluted to a certain factor, 50 ml of washing solution was uniformly coated on the BHI/LB agar plate. After the solution was cultured anaerobically for 48 h, the bacterial colonies were counted.

sections.heading: 2.4.3.2. SEM observation of the surface adhesion of bacteria.
sections.text:
The sterile samples were co-cultured with 2 ml bacterial suspension (1 × 109 CFU L−1) under an anaerobic environment for 24 h. All samples were then extracted sequentially from the bacterial suspension and rinsed thrice with sterile PBS buffer solution to remove the non-adherent bacteria. The bacteria cultured on the surface of the samples were fixed with a volume fraction of 2.5% glutaraldehyde (Sigma, USA) for 24 h at4 ◦C. The samples were removed and rinsed with sterile PBS buffer thrice, and then dehydrated with 30%, 50%, 70%, 80%, 90%, 100%, and 100% (v/v) graded ethanol, successively, with 15 min incubation at each concentration. The samples were dried by a vacuum dryer at a critical point of CO2 and sprayed with gold coating before the SEM observation.

3. Results
3.1. Characterization of the sample surface
Compared with the PEEK group, the surface of the nano-silver coating groups was slightly gray. With the increase of the coating thickness, their colors did not significantly change.
Fig. 2 shows the SEM topography of the surfaces of all the samples. The surfaces of the PEEK samples in the control group were relatively smooth without the nano-particles. After magnetron sputtering, uniformly distributed Ag nanoparticles (AgNPs) were visible on the surfaces of the samples in PEEK-3, PEEK-6, PEEK-9, and PEEK-12. The silver particles were round and compact, and when the silver content increased, the arrangement of the silver particles became compact.
Fig. 3 displays the results of the surface element analysis on the PEEKs and nano-silver coated PEEKs. EDS observation results showed that the surfaces of the modified PEEKs had silver elements, unlike the surfaces of the pure PEEKs. Furthermore, when the thickness of the nano-silver coating increased, the peak of the silver element gradually increased.
Fig. 4 and Table 2 display the three-dimensional morphology and surface roughness analyzed separately through AFM. As shown in Fig. 4, the three-dimensional morphologies of the PEEK group and the nano-silver coated groups

After surfaces of the samples were modified, the urface water contact angles of the modified samples were ncreased, and the differences among the contact angles of he samples were statistically significant (P < 0.01). The cell absorbance value and RGR values and cytotoxicity grade are shown in Tables 3 and 4, respectively. As shown in Table 3, the A values of the negative control group, blank control group, and PEEK group were basically similar. The A value of the nano-silver coated groups were not statistically different from those of the negative control, blank control, and PEEK groups (P > 0.05). Moreover, no significant difference was observed between the A values of the nano-silver coating groups (P > 0.05). The PEEK and nano-silver coating groups were significantly different (P < 0.01) from the positive control, negative control, and blank control groups,
The results from Table 4 showed that the negative control, PEEK, and nano-silver coating groups showed good RGR values. At different time points, the cytotoxic grades and RGR values of the negative control, PEEK, PEEK-3, PEEK-6, and PEEK9 groups were 0 and more than 100%, respectively. Although the RGR of PEEK-12 group in 1 day and 3 days was less than 100%, it remained more than 90% with toxicity grade of I grade. Thus, PEEK-12 was considered as a safe material. Consequently, although the thickness and silver content of the nano-silver coatings from the PEEK-3 to the PEEK-12 groups increased, the RGR values of these groups remained 100% or 97%. The PEEK and nano-silver coated PEEKs did not exhibit cytotoxicity, and thus can still be considered as biologically safe materials.

3.2.2.1. SEM observation of the surface adhesion bacteria. The SEM results of S. mutans that adhered on the surface of samples are shown in Fig. 12. A large number of S. mutans colonies adhered on the surface of PEEK sample, which was mostly covered by bacteria. In contrast, the S. mutans colonies that adhered on the surface of nano-silver coated samples were significantly lesser in number than that on the PEEK sample (P < 0.01) and were more dispersed. With the increase in the thickness of the nano-silver coating, the amount of S. mutans on the surface of the sample and surface area covered by S. mutans was gradually reduced. Among the groups, PEEK-12 had the least amount of S. mutans on the surface and area covered by S. mutans. As observed through high magnification microscope, The S. mutans colonies on the surface of PEEK showed a long chain or reunion. In the PEEK group, the surface with bacteria was smooth, and the cell membrane was continuous, complete, dark, and dense, and had its surrounding was clean. By contrast, the long chain of S. mutans on the surface of a nano-silver coated PEEK was fractured. Moreover, the S. mutans colony on the surface of PEEK-12 was completely broken and showed a single spherical shape with rough surface and different degrees of swelling.
The adhesion of S. aureus on the PEEK surface was clearly observed on the SEM images, as shown in Fig. 13. Numerous S. aureus colonies adhered on the surface of the PEEK sample. Compared with PEEK, the nano-silver coated samples had a significantly lesser amount S. aureus (P < 0.01), which was dis-

4. Discussion
PEEK and its composite materials exhibit high strength, high rigidity, corrosion resistance, hydrolysis resistance, mechan-
ace: (A) PEEK; (B) PEEK-3; (C) PEEK-6; (D) PEEK-9; (E) PEEK-12.
d e n t a l m a t e r i a l s 3 3 ( 2 0 1 7 ) xxx.e348–xxx.e360 xxx.e357
3 ( 2 xxx.e358 d e n t a l m a t e r i a l s 3
ical properties, and good biological compatibility and have satisfactory clinical effects; thus, they are used in various applications, such as repair of bone defect, wound healing, and oral implants [8–10,24]. For the reduction of the incidence of peri-implant inflammation and improvement of the success rate of implants, current research focus on methods that can improve the antibacterial properties of PEEKs without compromising their biological activities [25].
In the current experiment, nano-silver coating was prepared on the surface of PEEK through magnetron sputtering. The nano-silver coated PEEK exhibited significantly improved antibacterial property and was biologically safe.
The results of SEM and EDS showed that the silver nanoparticles were arranged in a dense and uniform arrangement without any agglomeration. Nano-silver coating was successfully prepared on the surface of PEEK material. The results of AFM and water contact angle measurements showed that the surface roughness and the contact angles of nano-silver coated PEEKs increased significantly.
The excited silver ions strongly impact the PEEK under the acceleration of electric field and magnetic field, resulting in the etching on the surface of PEEK, and the silver ions are also polymerized on the surface of PEEK, resulting in the formation of nanoscale surface topography. At the same time, the surface roughness increases. Generally speaking, the larger surface roughness of the material, the greater the surface area of the contact of the osteoblast on the surface and often leads to the better adhesion and growth of bone cells [11,26,27]. The increase of roughness is beneficial to the osseointegration of PEEK implants in vivo, which lays a good foundation for the later osteogenesis experiment.
Medical nano-silver materials must be biologically safe before they can be used in clinical applications. Silver ions are released from the silver solution and deposited in cells. Silver ions have the same size as some biomolecules (such as DNA and proteins) and thus can directly act on DNA or protein, destroy DNA, denature proteins, destroy mitochondrial membranes, produce free radicals, and induce the apoptosis pathway, which can all lead to cell death [28–31]. In the current study, nano-silver damaged the cell walls and cell membranes of bacteria, indicating that it can penetrate into the cells and subsequently destroy the cell organelles, such as mitochondria and ribosomes. In addition, the nano-silver caused chromatin condensation and marginalization, which are the important indicators of apoptosis. Nano-silver is small and thus it can adhere to the cell surface and then directly enter into a cell, and finally promote cell death without destroying the cell membrane [32]. However, some studies reported that a small amount of silver ion in cell cannot undergo rapid deposition, and thus it cannot react with the cell content [33]. In the current study, the PEEK and the coating groups were significantly different from the positive control group at different time points. Meanwhile, they were not significantly different from the blank control group. The PEEK group remained biologically safe before and after modification. The reason was that few or no silver ion was release from the silver coating group and the amount of silver ion is not sufficient to induce apoptosis. The results of Kim et al. [34] showed that nanosilver ions must be more than 300 mg/l before it they cause mild liver injury. In addition, some studies emphasized that
0 1 7 ) xxx.e348–xxx.e360
the human body had some related genes, metal detoxification mechanism, and free radical scavenging mechanism that can resist the cytotoxic effect of silver ions [35].
Some studies showed that nano-silver exhibit good antibacterial effect against gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria [28,36]. However, its antibacterial mechanism remains unclear. Oberdörster et al. [37] proposed that the antibacterial mechanism of AgNPs is the same as that of silver ions. AgNPs have small particle diameters and thus they can easily invade pathogens and induce rapid binding with the thiol groups of enzymes or proteins; this binding process can reduce the activity of biological enzyme, and thus can lead to rapid death of bacteria by metabolism disorder [38]. In addition, the antibacterial mechanism of nano-silver in proteomics was also studied. After bacteria interact with nano-silver, the envelope protein precursor of the bacteria accumulates and its cell membrane potential decreases; this effect destroys the bacterial cell membrane and disrupts its permeability; thus, the intracellular ATP level decreases, and the cells fail to produce energy [39]. Mi et al. [40] found that nano-silver can combine with bacteria DNA and destroy its structure. This resulting DNA degeneration inhibits replication, consequently disrupting the bacterial reproduction. In addition, AgNPs can directly interact with bacteria and thus can induce structural changes and functional damage on the plasma membrane; these effects can lead to cytoplasm leakage and bacteriolysis [16]. In the current study, the coating groups had strong antibacterial effects on two kinds of bacteria. Their antibacterial rates were above 99%, indicating that the nano-silver coated PEEK implant materials has strong antibacterial and bactericidal effects against S. mutans and S. aureus in the oral cavity.
Bacterial adhesion and biofilm on the surface of material are the two important factors that can lead to peri-implant inflammation and implant failure [41]. Previous studies showed that the adhesion and colonization of bacteria on the surface of materials are affected by surface roughness, free energy, charge, and hydrophobicity. Surface roughness is the dominant factor affecting plaque formation. Rough implant surface is beneficial to bacterial adhesion, whereas smooth surface can reduce bacterial adhesion [42,43]. However, in recent years, researchers have found that the surface roughness is not positively correlated with the number of bacterial adhesion [44]. The results of surface roughness analysis showed that although the surface roughness of nano-silver modified PEEK increased, the surface roughness of all samples remained below 0.2 m. Bollen et al. [45] studied the relationship between roughness and bacterial adhesion. Their results showed that when Ra >0.2 m, the increase in surface roughness can promote bacterial adhesion, whereas when Ra <0.2 m, the total amount and pathogenicity of the bacteria adhering to the surface of material do not change with the changes in roughness. This result suggests that 0.2 m is the reference value for surface roughness of implant materials. Therefore, in the current experiment, the surface roughness of each group sample has no significant effect on bacterial adhesion to the surface of samples. The variation in the quantities of viable bacteria on the surface of materials of the coating groups is caused by the antibacterial adhesion of silver coating at varying thicknesses.

The hydrophobicity is another dominant factor affecting acterial adhesion and biofilm formation. The hydrophoicity of a material plays an important role in the initial dhesion of bacteria on its surface. The greater the water conact angle of the material, the greater the hydrophobicity is, hus, bacteria are less likely to adhere [46]. The hydrophilic egree of each nano-silver coated PEEK was analyzed by easuring its surface water contact angle. After magnetron puttering, the surface water contact angle of nano-silver oated PEEK increased significantly, and the hydrophobicity ncreased. This effect counteracted the adhesion of S. mutans nd S. aureus on its surface. Studies showed that the surace roughness of material has certain effects on surface ydrophobicity. When the surface water contact angle is >90◦, he contact angle increases with the increase of surface roughess; hence, the surface becomes more hydrophobic [47]. The urface water contact angle of nano-silver coated groups was reater than 90◦, and when the thickness of the nano-silver oating increased, the water contact angle and surface roughess increased as well. This result corresponds to the reported iterature. However, the current study presented some limitations. or example, hydrophobic coating can inhibit bacterial adheion and thus destroys biofilm formation. However, bacteria ave the same mechanism of adhesion on the surface of aterials as normal cells, and thus the combination of aterials and surrounding tissues must be considered. Idelly, nano-silver coated PEEK implant materials can produce atisfactory antibacterial and adhesion–disinfection effects ithout affecting normal cell functions. At present, many tudies have reported the behavior of cells on different ydrophobic surfaces. However, no consistent conclusion as reached. Some researchers prepared super hydrophoic surface with contact angle of 167◦ ± 2◦, and found that
hydrophobic surface can promote the adhesion and proiferation of bone marrow stromal stem cells (BMCS); the romotion effect is increasingly evident after 24 h [48]. Zhang t al. [49] found that the number of osteoblasts adhering to he super hydrophobic surface was significantly less than that f the normal surface cultured for 24 h; however, the numer of cells that adhered to the super hydrophobic surface ncreased after 24 h compared with the number of cells that dhered to the normal surface. Although the super hydrophoic coating was not conducive to osteoblast adhesion, it had no ffect on osteoblast proliferation. The amount of cell adhesion ecreased after culturing for 24 h, but the super hydrophobic urface facilitated cell adhesion and proliferation after 24 h. n the current experiment, the hydrophobicity of the material as enhanced, and the antibacterial activity was increased fter modification with silver coating. However, the effect on he bioactivity of the cell needs further study.
. Conclusions
he compact and homogeneous nano-silver modified layer as successfully prepared on the surface of PEEK by magetron sputtering. The modified PEEK implants exhibited nhanced antibacterial activity and bacterial adhesion ability nd did not exhibit cytotoxicity.

After bacteria interact with nano-silver, the envelope protein precursor of the bacteria accumulates and its cell membrane potential decreases; this effect destroys the bacterial cell membrane and disrupts its permeability; thus, the intracellular ATP level decreases, and the cells fail to produce energy [39].
[40] found that nano-silver can combine with bacteria DNA and destroy its structure.

In addition, AgNPs can directly interact with bacteria and thus can induce structural changes and functional damage on the plasma membrane; these effects can lead to cytoplasm leakage and bacteriolysis [16].
Bacterial adhesion and biofilm on the surface of material are the two important factors that can lead to peri-implant inflammation and implant failure [41].
Rough implant surface is beneficial to bacterial adhesion, whereas smooth surface can reduce bacterial adhesion [42,43].
Rough implant surface is beneficial to bacterial adhesion, whereas smooth surface can reduce bacterial adhesion [42,43].
However, in recent years, researchers have found that the surface roughness is not positively correlated with the number of bacterial adhesion [44].
[45] studied the relationship between roughness and bacterial adhesion.
The greater the water conact angle of the material, the greater the hydrophobicity is, hus, bacteria are less likely to adhere [46].
When the surface water contact angle is >90◦, he contact angle increases with the increase of surface roughess; hence, the surface becomes more hydrophobic [47].

Some researchers prepared super hydrophoic surface with contact angle of 167◦ ± 2◦, and found that hydrophobic surface can promote the adhesion and proiferation of bone marrow stromal stem cells (BMCS); the romotion effect is increasingly evident after 24 h [48].

[49] found that the number of osteoblasts adhering to he super hydrophobic surface was significantly less than that f the normal surface cultured for 24 h; however, the numer of cells that adhered to the super hydrophobic surface ncreased after 24 h compared with the number of cells that dhered to the normal surface.

metadata.abstractText: Objectve. We aimed to investigate the cytotoxicity and antibacterial properties of nano-silvercoated polyetheretherketone (PEEK) produced through magnetron sputtering and provide a theoretical basis for its use in clinical applications. Methods. The surfaces of PEEKs were coated with nano-silver at varying thicknesses (3, 6, 9, and 12 nm) through magnetron sputtering technology. The resulting coated PEEK samples were classified into the following groups according to the thickness of the nano-silver coating: PEEK-3 (3 nm), PEEK-6 (6 nm), PEEK-9 (9 nm), PEEK-12 (12 nm), and PEEK control group. The surface microstructure and composition of each sample were observed by scanning electron microscopy (SEM), atomic force microscopy (AFM), and energy dispersive spectrum (EDS) analysis. The water contact angle of each sample was then measured by contact angle meters. A cell counting kit (CCK-8) was used to analyze the cytotoxicity of the mouse fibroblast cells (L929) in the coated groups (n = 5) and group test samples (n = 6), negative control (polyethylene, PE) (n = 6), and positive control group (phenol) (n = 6). The antibacterial properties of the samples were tested by co-culturing Streptococcus mutans and Straphylococcus aureus. The bacteria that adhered to the surface of samples were observed by SEM. The antibacterial adhesion ability of each sample was then evaluated. Results. SEM and AFM analysis results showed that the surfaces of control group samples were smooth but compact. Homogeneous silver nano-particles (AgNPs) and nano-silver coating were uniformly distributed on the surface of the coated group samples. Compared with the control samples, the nano-silver coated samples had a significant increase in surface roughness (P < 0.05) as the thickness of their nano-silver coating increased. EDS analysis showed that not only C and O but also Ag were present on the surface of the coated samples. Moreover, the water contact angle of modified samples significantly increased after nanosilver coating modification (P < 0.01). CCK-8 cytotoxicity test results showed that coated samples did not exhibit cytotoxicity. The antibacterial experimental results showed that the nano-silver coating can significantly improve the antibacterial activity and bacterial adhesion ability of the PEEK samples. Significance. The compact and homogeneous nano-silver coating was successfully prepared ∗ Corresponding author. Fax: +86 431 88975348. E-mail address: jdliuhong@163.com (H. The nano-silver coated PEEKs demonstrated enhanced antibacterial activities and bacterial adhesion abilities and had no cytotoxic effects. © 2017 The Academy of Dental Materials.
